item.title: Black Crescent Vale
item.description: Nestled between the River of Tyranny and the River of Sorrow, the northern half of the nation of Legionhold is occupied by a dense, twisted forest that fell to a powerful corruption many millennia ago. Corrupt beasts often try to escape the Vale in an attempt to spread their corruption to the surrounding region but are kept in check by the militant branch of the Black Crescent Legion.

Black marbling extends out from the cliffs in places, continuing their imitation of lightning dashing across the sky. These are known as Lightning Sprouts, and are a type of magically infused fungus formed of striations or shelves of subtly color shifting sprouts. They are conductive and are known to draw lightning to them during storms. They are particularly dangerous during the Season of Flux, wherein they become nearly permanently charged and lightning continuously arcs off of their surface. Magic users in Kel Soren often involve lightning in their rituals as a way of harnessing their energy
Most buildings are carved into the abundant cliff faces, their borders often following the sharp lines of the black marbling. There are occasional exceptions to this, but these exception do their best to mimic the aesthetic of the cliffs

item.title: Primordial Deities
item.description:
The pantheon of deities acknowledged by all Mortal Races. It is said that the Primordial Deities originally bestowed sentience upon the Mortal Races when they first came to Ashmara. Once, the Primordial Deities walked among the Mortal Races, directly involving themselves in their affairs. Ever since the exodus of the Mortal Races from Ashmara, the Primordial Deities have grown distant, still bestowing their Clerics and Champions with their deific powers, but no longer directly involving themselves with the Mortal Races.
The Primordial Deities' pantheon is comprised of:

Andasaryth, Goddess of Might
Tarak, God of War
Nakorat, God of Trickery
Erydath, God of Death
Saleshan, Goddess of Redemption & Peace
Myrthalis, God of Justice
Krosar, God of Tyranny
Tsarok, Goddess of Freedom
Though this is primary pantheon of deities recognized by the Mortal Races, it is not the only pantheon of deities worshipped by the people of Kalcrea. Each of the Mortal Races also has their own pantheon or individual deity that they recognize (often collectively known as the Ancestral Paragons) in addition to the patron deities which may have different names or depictions across Kalcrea but ultimately refer to the same being.

item.title: Ashmara
item.description: The home world of the Mortal Races, lost long ago to a catastrophe long forgotten that forced the Mortal Races into exile. With the aid of the Primordial Deities, the Mortal Races escaped Ashmara via colossal Astral Gateways that linked Ashmara with its three moons: Valekath, Tarkull, and Kalcrea. Ultimately, Valekath and Tarkull were utterly destroyed, and the remains of the Mortal Races found themselves confined to Kalcrea, the Astral Gateways that had brought them there originally now lost in the sundering of Stradeum, Seat of the Gods.

item.title: Astral Rings
item.description:
Two asteroid belts, known as the Astral Rings to the Kalcreans, surround the moon. These Astral Rings are the remnants of two of Ashmara's moons, Tarkull and Valekath, worlds which were not dissimilar to Kalcrea itself. Stories tell that the Primordial Deities wove the shattered pieces of the planets into a protective barrier around Kalcrea, infusing them with immense arcane energies to prevent whatever cataclysm befell the rest of the Mortal Expanse from reaching Kalcrea. Swirling fluxes of arcane energy are visible within the Astral Rings, weaving complex patterns and changing colours with the seasons. These beautiful lights are visible faintly during the day but are noticeable even through clouds during the night.
The Astral Rings split Kalcrea into four regions, each of which experiences its own weather seasons independently. These regions are known as: The Aurean Eye, The Eternal Eye, The Deific Span, and The Forgotten Span. Additionally, there are the confluences: the regions beneath the intersections of the Astral Rings. The Aetherborn Confluence looms above The Fellhaunt in the Obsidian Wastes while the Agyran Confluence lies above the southern edge of the Agyran Peaks, just north of Lef' Yrtha.

item.title: Kalcrea
item.description: The only remaining moon of Ashmara, and the current home of the Mortal Races.

item.title: Sorith
item.description: The star at the center of the star system to which Kalcrea and Ashmara belong.

item.title: Tarkull
item.description: Previously the nearest orbiting satellite to Ashmara, this moon was reduced to rubble when a now unknown cataclysm brought ruin to Ashmara and Valekath.

item.title: Valekath
item.description: Previously the furthest orbiting satellite from Ashmara, this moon was reduced to rubble when a now unknown cataclysm brought ruin to Ashmara and Tarkull.

item.title: Agyran
item.description: A term used to refer to a diverse cast of ancient beasts that have lived upon Kalcrea long before the arrival of the Mortal Races. These beasts typically dwarf an elephant and are as cunning as they are large.

item.title: Aetherborn Confluence
item.description: Located on the northern edge of the Obsidian Wastes, this is one of two regions that lies beneath an intersection of the Astral Rings.
item.guid: Mortal Expanse Reference/Glossary/Geography/Astral Rings - Divides and Confluences/Aetherborn Confluence.md

item.title: Agyran Confluence
item.description: Located just south of the Agyran Peaks, this is one of two regions that lies beneath an intersection of the Astral Rings.
item.guid: Mortal Expanse Reference/Glossary/Geography/Astral Rings - Divides and Confluences/Agyran Confluence.md

item.title: Agyran Peaks
item.description: A dense assembly of harsh mountains and lush, jungle valleys, these ancient and unforgiving lands are the only remaining home of the Agyran.

item.title: Planar Isles
item.description: A dense chain of islands surrounding the entirety of Stradeum which is plagued by rifts – tears in the fabric of the mortal realm – to other realms.

item.title: Stradeum
item.description: Known also as the Seat of the Gods, Stradeum is a continent near the southern pole of Kalcrea. When the Mortal Races originally arrived upon Kalcrea, it was upon Stradeum that they arrived. Having eventually settled the rest of Kalcrea's continents, the Mortal Races were forced to retreat back to the protection of the Primordial Deities upon Stradeum when an unknown devastation brought the rest of the Mortal Expanse to ruin, leaving the remainders of their civilizations on Kalcrea to crumble. Ultimately, they would flee Stradeum and return to the now untamed wilds of Kalcrea's other continents when Stradeum was sundered and the Planar Isles were formed, marking the end of the 4th cycle of the Mortal Expanse: the Cycle of Exodus, and the beginning of the 5th cycle, the Cycle of Aspiration.

item.title: The Aurean Eye
item.description: The seasonal region spanning from the eastern edge of Lef' Yrtha to the western edge of The Fellhaunt.

item.title: The Deific Span
item.description: The seasonal region encompassing all things south of the bounds of The Aurean Eye and The Eternal Eye.

item.title: The Eternal Eye
item.description: The seasonal region spanning from the eastern edge of The Fellhaunt to the western edge of Lef' Yrtha.

item.title: The Forgotten Span
item.description: The seasonal region encompassing all things north of the bounds of The Aurean Eye and The Eternal Eye.

item.title: Confluence
item.description: The Confluences are the points at which the Astral Rings intersect in the skies above Kalcrea. Beneath these Confluences, the current season is a sporadic mix between the current seasons of each Astral Ring, though it is primarily determined by Valekath, as it is the closer of the two Astral Rings. During the Arcane Seasons, the Confluences become dangerous places as the seasons' effects are amplified dramatically.

item.title: Spark
item.description: Between each season is a transitionary day known as a Spark. This day presents as a blending of the two seasons it is transitioning between. During the spark, the arcane energies in the Astral Rings become more active and shed more light than usual, bathing the planet in a constant, eerie, arcane light bright enough to provide dim light even at night.

item.title: Astraseer
item.description: Arcane researchers who study the Astral Rings hoping to decipher its patterns, motions, and colors in order to predict the changing of the seasons upon Kalcrea.

item.title: Arcane Seasons - Seasons of Flux and of Stability
item.description: In addition to the four normal seasons of Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter, the Kalcreans experience two arcane seasons: one of flux, and one of stability. These two seasons occur when specific combinations of seasons occur in the Astral Rings. The Season of Flux occurs when the two seasons are opposite to one another (Summer & Winter, or Spring & Autumn) and the Season of Stability occurs when the two seasons are the same. Unlike the normal seasons, which affect only the lands situated beneath their Astral Ring, the arcane seasons are a global phenomenon. In areas where the Astral Rings overlap, the arcane seasons are more extreme, and often more dangerous. During these seasons, the light from the Astral Rings is more intense, providing dim light even during the night.
item.guid: Mortal Expanse Reference/Glossary/Seasons/Arcane Seasons - Seasons of Flux and of Stability.md

item.title: Season of Flux
item.description: One of the two arcane seasons Kalcrea experiences. Bolts of lightning slowly churn their way through skies that are thick with arcane energies. These sources of energy intermingle as the arcane slowly twists and forms some bolts into coalescences of plasma that are carried off in the intense and ever-present winds.

item.title: Season of Stability
item.description: A dense fog overtakes the world as all moisture is caught in a strange arcane field slightly above the ground. Eerie glows and lights reflect through the fog – a result of the increased arcane activity in the Astral Rings – sparking wild tales and folklore among different cultures of Kalcrea. At the end of the season, all the suspended moisture drops out of the sky in a massive deluge after a brief period of light rain, threatening floods and damage even to sturdy structures. Upon the advent of this season, the people of Kalcrea can be seen reinforcing rooftops and digging flood troughs in preparation for the end of the season.

item.title: Astral Gateways
item.description:
Tales tell of ancient Astral Gateways, built in conjunction by the Mortal Races and the Primordial Deities, which allowed for travel amongst the various worlds of the Mortal Expanse. It is using these that the mortals first arrived on Kalcrea, Tarkull, and Valekath from Ashmara, and it is using them that the people of Kalcrea hope to one day return to Ashmara. Despite their ambitions, the Mortal Races remain unable to confirm the existence of such a gateway upon Kalcrea, much less make use of it.
Their struggles lies in that the Astral Gateway upon Kalcrea is said to be in the center of Stradeum, known also as the Seat of the Gods, the continent upon which the mortal races first established themselves on Kalcrea, and which they fled back to as the rest of the Mortal Expanse fell to ruin. This continent now lies shattered, its fringes torn into what is now known as the Planar Isles, a dense chain of islands surrounding the entirety of Stradeum which is plagued by rifts – tears in the fabric of the mortal realm – to other realms. Creatures and elements from these planes pour onto the isles, rendering them uninhabitable and unnavigable, as even the sturdiest ships cannot withstand an onslaught of planar entities or an ocean disturbed by the torrential planar energies pervasive throughout the isles.

item.title: Mortal Expanse
item.description: Refers to all celestial bodies and regions of space that have been inhabited by the Mortal Races.

item.title: Mortal Races
item.description: A term commonly used to refer to the races that were granted sentience by the Primordial Deities. Primarily refers to Humans, Elves, Dwarves, Halflings, Gnomes, Goblins, and Orcs, but is not limited to these.

item.title: Span
item.description: A Span refers to a period of 10 days and is used in the same way we would refer to a period of 7 days as a week.

item.title: Succession
item.description: Much as our calendar year represents one full orbit of our planet around the Sun, a Kalcrean Succession represents two coinciding events: the completion of Ashmara's orbit around its star, Sorith, and the completion of 10 seasons, and 500 days, on Kalcrea.

item.title: Depths of the Everwell Player's Guide
item.description:
The Astral Rings, looming high above the skies of Kalcrea, have grown lively over the last few days, their entrancing lights dancing eagerly along their intersecting orbits. A pale green glow alight with ribbons of vibrant blue dominates the rings. In their readings of the complex patterns and motions of the Astral Rings, the Astraseers of Kel Soren claim that a Season of Flux is imminent. Being the first Season of Flux of this Succession, it's coming will mark the Spark of First Refuge for the residents of Kel Soren, a celebration which honors the town's founder, Ilithi, and her perilous flight from the Black Crescent Vale over 2000 years ago.
As residents of Kel Soren, your group is busy preparing to embark upon a pilgrimage which often marks one's first steps beyond the confines of Kel Soren's marbled walls and its surrounding forest, The Whispering Pines. Pilgrims depart from Kel Soren upon the dawn of the Spark of the First Flux, which is expected to arrive at the end this Span, and travel north until they reach the southern edge of the Black Crescent Vale. There, the pilgrims make camp for the night and then return to Kel Soren the next day. They must arrive before the gates of Kel Soren close to consider their pilgrimage a success. To remain true to Ilithi's journey, pilgrims bring only their clothes, a single waterskin, a small backpack which they can fill with whatever they desire, and a single tool or weapon of their choice. They are also encouraged to perform the pilgrimage in small groups in order to foster the spirit of community and selflessness that Ilithi embodied.
Your mentors are running your through your last tasks and drills to ensure you are ready to take on this long journey; being so close to the Aetherborn Confluence means that the Season of Flux can be quite dangerous, and there will be much ground to cover. As the days dwindle and anticipation builds, you receive word from your mentor that Alovir Valore, the librarian at the Primordial Court Library, is seeking some assistance from you and your friends with a small task...
item.guid: Depths of the Everwell Player's Guide.md
